body: can you add a test that reproduces the segfault (and this PR fixes)

this is going to need a run of the asv suite for the csv benchmarks to see if anything changed. see [here](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/contributing.html#running-the-performance-test-suite)

The full results are in the attached archive.
[results.tar.gz](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/files/383080/results.tar.gz)
I added a [test](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/pull/13788/commits/0d0d66026ce231bca23cfe00c686edb4d386f332) that check for either segfault, or memory corruption during parsing.

@ivannz You pulled in some changes from other PRs that have been merged recently. Can you rebase to fix this? Normally

```
git fetch upstream
git rebase upstream/master
git push -f origin parser_trim_fix
```

should do the trick

For the asv benchmarks, you will need to compare to current master to see if anything changed. In fact, we just did merge a pull request to clarify how to do this (https://github.com/pydata/pandas/pull/13794):

```
asv continuous upstream/master HEAD -b csv
```

tests are just like any other parser test
put in io/tests/parser/common.py

I had to update the stressfulness of the test, because sometimes [**safe_realloc**](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/src/parser/tokenizer.c#L47) just expands the **parser->stream** buffer, which does not corrupt the pointers in **parser->words**.

@jreback , I rewrote the test as you suggested. It is a problem if `nosetests` does not recover from `segfault` when run on it?
@ivannz the whole point is for it NOT to recover. A segfault is as noticiable as any other error. If you have a test that segfaults, and it is fixed, it will pass.

I added a note in whatsnew / bug fix section of **`v0.19.0.txt`**.

I am not sure how to concisely put it for a general user, but whether the bug occurs, and its severity (a segfault or memory corruption) depends on the state of the system memory allocator. Specifically it is the result of the interplay between the inner logics of **realloc** implementation and the availability of memory regions adjacent to the **realloced** buffer:
- sometimes **realloc** just expands the buffer, leaving its starting address intact -- in this case **no bug takes place**;
- other times **realloc** moves a buffer to a new location, and in this case there are two alternatives:
  1. the old block is invalidated, but is still accessible to the parser, in which case the tokenized strings in **parser->words** (which is a char\* array) become **corrupted**;
  2. the old block is invalidated and reclaimed by the OS, in which case the process **crashes with a segfault**.

The first alternative manifests itself in **NaNs**, or otherwise unacceptable **ASCII** characters (beyond 128) in fields where no such thing is possible by design (BCD or textual decimal fields).

Every time the unpatched `parser_trim_buffers` is invoked by either [parser.pyx:_read_low_memory()](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/parser.pyx#L851) or [parser.pyx:_read_rows()](https://github.com/pydata/pandas/blob/master/pandas/parser.pyx#L902) there is a risk of this undefined behaviour.
ok @ivannz just say that on large chunking _may_ segfault then.

Is there a way to cancel all but the most recent Travis job related to this PR (13788)?

The most recent is this one: **`job # 21105`**

@ivannz I canceled some builds (but there are some other PRs in the queue as well, so will take some time anyway). Only solution is to not push a minor commit yet if you know you are going to push another one (or to put 'ci skip').  
BTW, you can set up travis for your own fork, which often gives you much quicker feedback, and there you yourself have control over the builds (eg to cancel them).
Thank you, @jorisvandenbossche !
I significantly improved the clarity and logic of the segfault/corruption test: now it is a bit more clear why and in what case the bug occurs.
@jorisvandenbossche , could you cancel Travis CI job #21105, please.
thanks!

I tried to compile master branch on Windows VS2015 and it failed with the errors:

```
pandas/src/parser/tokenizer.c(1260): error C2036: 'void *': unknown size
pandas/src/parser/tokenizer.c(1264): error C2036: 'void *': unknown size
```

So I guess `newptr` in these two lines should be cast to `char *`.
can u make a new issue? and fix if u can
OK. I'll later submit the fix.
